Tracing cell lineages and studying human development;

Tracing cell ancestries (i.e.
column2: lineages) is fundamental to understanding the principles of development in multicellular organisms and unraveling complex biological processes involving the differentiation of diverse cell types with distinct lineage hierarchies. In humans
column3: direct experimental lineage tracing is not ethically feasible
column4: so researchers must rely on naturally occurring mutations that arise as cells divide and age. Our group has shown that it is possible to reconstruct lineages in normal
column5: noncancerous human cells using natural variations in both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA
column6: drawing on diverse types of genomic data. We are particularly focused on studying cell ancestries ancestry during the earliest stages of human development
column7: including germline lineage tracing across generations. Our work had shed light on how early pre-gastrulation lineages are transmitted and contribute to the ongoing evolution of the human genome. With advances in genomic technologies and analytical methods
column8: the scientific community is approaching a major milestone: the construction of a comprehensive
column9:
high-resolution map of human embryonic and fetal cell lineages. We are committed to contributing to this transformative effort including contribution to the SMaHT project.

Single cell studies;

Single-cell sequencing is a powerful approach for studying somatic mosaicism in both healthy tissues and cancer. However
column2: because a single cell contains only a limited amount of DNA
column3: amplification is necessary prior to sequencing. This can be achieved through clonal expansion—culturing a single cell to form a colony—or through in vitro whole-genome amplification (WGA) using polymerases. We are currently developing strategies to ensure the quality control of WGA and to distinguish true biological signal from artifacts introduced during cell culture or DNA amplification. In parallel
column4:
we are designing methods to estimate the respective contributions of signal and noise in cases where they cannot be clearly separated.

CNV and CNA analysis;

Copy number variation (CNV) in the genome is a complex phenomenon that remains incompletely understood. Frequent in cancers
column2: somatic copy number alterations (CNA) have been related to cancer susceptibility
column5: and patients’ quality of life after treatment. The detection of CNVs and CNAs is important to address a wide spectrum of clinical and scientific questions. Research in our laboratory is focused on the discovery and analysis of CNVs and CNAs along with their relevance to diseases. We have developed and continually improved a method
column7: for CNV discovery and genotyping from a read-depth analysis of personal genome or cancer sequencing that currently ranks among the best
column8:
most widely used methods for CNV analysis.

Variant function;

Advances in transcriptomic and epigenomic profiling techniques
column3: provide powerful opportunities to study the consequences of genomic variants—both inherited and somatic—particularly in non-coding regions of the genome where their effects remain poorly understood. Our laboratory is focused on elucidating such effects
column4: with an emphasis on variants that contribute to neurodevelopmental disorders such as autism spectrum disorder and Tourette syndrome (TS). Recently
column5: leveraging single-nucleus transcriptomic and open chromatin datasets from the postmortem striatum of adult TS patients and matched controls
column6: we analyzed gene expression and chromatin accessibility across defined cell types. These analyses revealed a reduction in GABAergic and cholinergic interneurons in TS brains. Additional findings suggest that interneuron loss leads to chronic hyperactivity of medium spiny neurons
column9:
and disruption of basal ganglia homeostasis. Our ongoing work seeks to further define the regulatory landscape of TS using an expanded sample set.

column1:
Mosaic somatic mutations in humans;

Mutations that accumulate in DNA throughout an individual’s life give rise to a mosaic body
column2: where each cell carries a unique set of genetic alterations — a phenomenon known as somatic mosaicism. Although somatic mosaicism is widespread
column3: its study has been limited by challenges in detecting such variants
column4: both at the single-cell level and in bulk tissue samples. Our group has developed computational methods to accurately detect somatic mosaic mutations by leveraging deep whole-genome sequencing of human tissue samples. Using this approach
column5: we discovered that in the human brain
column6: certain cells undergo clonal expansion with age
column7:
outcompeting their peers and leading to an increased burden of detectable mosaic mutations — a phenomenon we refer to as brain hypermutability. We found that this overgrowth is associated with damaging mutations in cancer driver genes. Our ongoing work focuses on uncovering the origin of this phenomenon and identifying the specific cell type(s) responsible for the clonal expansion.
